Logical Operators in Javascript

Arun v Â  in India
Tue Jun 15 2021
  • Logical_Operator
  • Javascript

# Logical Operators

Logical operators are typically used with Boolean (logical) values; when they are, they return a Boolean value. However, the && and || operators actually return the value of one of the specified operands, so if these operators are used with non-Boolean values, they may return a non-Boolean value. The logical operators are described in the following table.

# AND operator

AND operator (&&) is used when we are using a multiple condition and all the condition has to be true for instance

let condition1 = true;
let condition2 = true;
let andCondition = condition1 && condition2; // true
if (andCondition) {
	// code will be executed
}

# OR operator

OR operator (||) is used when we have multiple condition and we want to execute code if any one of the condition is true

let condition1 = true;
let condition2 = false;
let orCondition = condition1 || condition2; // true
if (orCondition) {
	// code will be executed
}

# Not operator

NOT operator (!) is used to invert the value if the value is true then it will turn that to false and vice versa

let condition1 = true;
let condition2 = false;
let andCondition = condition1 && condition2; // false
let notCondition = !andCondition;
if (notCondition) {
	// code will be executed
}

# Compares operator

# Double equal symbol

== is used to check if the value on the left hand side is equal to the vale on the right hand side no matter what the type the value is

console.log("one" == "one");
console.log("0" == 0);
// output
// true
// true

# Triple equal symbol

=== is similar to the double equal symbol but it also check the type on both side for match

// comparing different type
let condition1 = "0" === 0 // false
let condition2 = 0 === 0 // true
console.log(condition1);
console.log(condition2);
// output
// false
// true

# Greater or equal to symbol

> is used to check the value in the left hand side is greater than the value on the right side, >= is used to check the value on the left hand side is either greater than or equal to the value on the right hand side

let condition1 = 5 > 5;
let condition2 = 5 >= 5;
console.log(condition1);
console.log(condition2);
// output
// false
// true

# Lesser than or equal to symbol

< is used to check the value in the left hand side is lesser than the value on the right side, >= is used to check the value on the left hand side is either lesser than or equal to the value on the right hand side

let condition1 = 5 > 5;
let condition2 = 5 >= 5;
console.log(condition1);
console.log(condition2);
// output
// false
// true

# Not equal to symbol

!= is used to check the value on the left hand side is not equal to the value on the right hand side

let condition = 5 != 10
console.log(condition);
// output
// true

# Truthy condition

In JavaScript, a truthy value is a value that is considered true when encountered in a Boolean context. All values are truthy unless they are defined as falsy (i.e., except for false, 0, -0, 0n, "", null, undefined, and NaN).

Examples of truthy values in JavaScript (which will be coerced to true in boolean contexts, and thus execute the if block):

if (true)
if ({})
if ([])
if (42)
if ("0")
if ("false")
if (new Date())
if (-42)
if (12n)
if (3.14)
if (-3.14)
if (Infinity)
if (-Infinity)
